catalog.title: Site Planning & Design
catalog.description: Examine the integration of requirements in site planning and design. Topics may include pedestrian movement and circulation; public transit; provisions for the handicapped; services and utilities; site assessment (including zoning, climate, topography, water and soil drainage, exploration, and testing); site work (including site preparation, earthwork, and foundations); site improvements (including landscaping); and sustainable design principles and standards. Cross-listed with URP 526 Site Planning & Design; students may not earn credit for both courses.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Found Historic Preservatn
catalog.description: Historic preservation theory related to planning and design, emphasizing preservation practice, including tools of effective preservation, legislation, community planning roles, economics, adaptive use, and management. Involves lectures, discussions, site visits, and fieldwork. May be offered on an intermittent basis. Cross-listed with END 528 Found Historic Preservatn and URP 528 Found Historic Preservatn; students may only earn course credit for one section.
catalog.subject: Architecture

notes.note: Classes to be held in computer lab.

catalog.title: Architectural Media 2
catalog.description: Expands further development in analog and digital graphic skill sets. Introduces intermediate 3d modeling techniques, basic rendering, digital / hybrid illustration, and post-processing techniques. Enhancement of technical skills, with introductory modeling for multiple outcomes to examine the link between product and methodology. Includes lectures, demonstrations, discussion, and production. Second in a three-course media sequence; open to admitted M. Arch. 3.5 students only or permission of the academic department.
catalog.subject: Architecture
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: ARC 503 or ARC 511 or ARC 553 or ARC 603 or ARC 611.
catalog.prerequisites: ARC 503 or ARC 511 or ARC 553 or ARC 603 or ARC 611

catalog.title: Architecture Design Studio 4
catalog.description: Topic is integrated architectural design. Synthesis of concept and construct, understanding design strategy, program, site, construction, and technology. Production of integrated design work will be informed by exploration of urban issues, history, culture, materiality, and craft. Design proposals will comprehensively address structural and environmental systems, life safety, accessibility, and material assemblies. Integrated engagement occurs through understanding aesthetic, technical, social, and environmental aspects of design, and considers matters ranging from the scale of the city to the tectonic detail. Includes lectures, discussion, and fieldwork. Fourth in a four-course design studio sequence; open to admitted M. Arch. 3.5 students only or permission of the academic department.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Architecture Design Studio 2
catalog.description: Explores the increasingly complex relationship between inhabitation and the built form. Architecture is triggered by a building program; a clientÂ¿s brief; or, a business plan, and examines how current economic realities create increasingly short building lifespans. Investigates how various architectural types and typologies have limited function, leading to premature redundancy, and untimely demolition of buildings. Develops awareness arising from programmatic misalignments and design dilemmas. Considers newly defined relationships between humans and the built environment, including a reevaluation of time, place, and space in architecture. Includes lectures, discussion, and fieldwork. Second in a four-course design studio sequence; open to admitted M. Arch. 3.5 students only or permission of the academic department.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Architecture History 2
catalog.description: Introduces the fundamentals of architectural design from the theory and practice of the 1450's to the built and written manifestos of modern times. Situates the evolution of the architectural discipline within the context of social, cognitive and technological transformation.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Architecture History 2
catalog.description: Introduces the fundamentals of architectural design from the theory and practice of the 1450's to the built and written manifestos of modern times. Situates the evolution of the architectural discipline within the context of social, cognitive and technological transformation.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Tech Methods: Urban Design
catalog.description: Technical methods in urban design and architecture works at the confluence of the scale of buildings and the scale of cities. Straddles the fields of architecture, urban planning, and development to critically examine parameters of contemporary urban form and forces.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Urban Design: Case Studies
catalog.description: Urban Design: Case Studies examines how American cities are so thinly spread out compared with many other nations. What is density and what does it mean? What are the relations between density and sustainability? This graduate seminar is intended to examine density as a most profound indicator of human settlement pattern especially in urbanized areas. One of hypotheses that the class addresses is this: Is denser the city, the greener it is or is it? Through the use of provocative readings and comparative analysis and mapping techniques, we compare major cities around the world to understand the relation between urban density and urbanism, its economic and environmental robustness: placemaking, good urban form and great streets -- all contributing to making cities great and robust ecologically, economically and socially.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Structures 1
catalog.description: A structures/construction course. Introduces the fundamentals of statics and strength of materials and the principals of structure. Provides a theoretical and scientific basis for understanding how various structural systems and structural materials work and withstand loading. Investigates the concepts introduced during the course with qualitative methods, as well as quantitative analysis. The course's scope is includes examining simple structural elements, such as trusses, beams, and columns used throughout our human designed built environment.
catalog.subject: Architecture
catalog.requisites_description: ARC 552 LEC and LAB must be taken together.
catalog.requisites: ARC 552 LEC and LAB must be taken together

catalog.title: Master's Portfolio
catalog.description: Examines how the design portfolio is an important communication tool for architects and designers to share their own project work. Introduces portfolio development processes, incorporating action research for the cultivation, selection, edited viewpoint, and presentation of individual work, concluding with a personal statement. Objectives include the development of a capstone design portfolio and documenting academic studio work, culminating in a professional format. Develops awareness to self-evaluate, organize, layout, and edit design work, embedding individual understanding for continued portfolio evolution throughout the post-collegiate, professional career.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Master's Portfolio

Introduces portfolio development processes, incorporating action research for the cultivation, selection, edited viewpoint, and presentation of individual work, concluding with a personal statement. notes.note: This class meets in Hayes Annex B-06.

catalog.title: Tech Methods: Material Culture
catalog.description: Material Culture projects forward from this history and the research group explores ways in which the culture of materials shapes our environments and contributes to our constructive sensibilities. Our research scrutinizes the transformation from idea to artifact. We seek to advance the process of design through full-scale fabrication, assembly and installation; critical exploration of design and production; and study of the potential of materials. In these investigations, the conceptual premises of architecture are consistently tested through making.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Tech Methods: Material Culture
catalog.description: Material Culture projects forward from this history and the research group explores ways in which the culture of materials shapes our environments and contributes to our constructive sensibilities. Our research scrutinizes the transformation from idea to artifact. We seek to advance the process of design through full-scale fabrication, assembly and installation; critical exploration of design and production; and study of the potential of materials. In these investigations, the conceptual premises of architecture are consistently tested through making.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Tech Methods: Ecological Pract
catalog.description: Offers students an intense exploration of the role that architects play in the design of the built and natural environments. Encourages multidisciplinary collaboration among allied professions and disciplines. Explores the following issues: connections among society, the economy, sustainability, and the environment; becoming familiar with various viewpoints of sustainable development; understanding how various types of analyses and visual communication techniques can be used to address environmental problems; techniques for measuring and visually representing the impact of environmental change; and other issues related to sustainable ecological practices. Topics vary annually. Includes lectures, discussions, site visits, and fieldwork.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Construction Tech
catalog.description: A structures/construction course. Emphasizes details of construction. Examines interfaces of materials and systems: foundation/wall, wall/window, wall/roof, floor/wall, etc. Investigates the effect of materials and processes on appearance and life of building components. Studies interior and exterior finishes, joints, fire protection, and specification. Open to admitted M. Arch. students only or permission of the academic department.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Construction Tech
catalog.description: A structures/construction course. Emphasizes details of construction. Examines interfaces of materials and systems: foundation/wall, wall/window, wall/roof, floor/wall, etc. Investigates the effect of materials and processes on appearance and life of building components. catalog.prerequisites: Graduate Students in the School of Architecture and Planning

catalog.title: Tech Method Situated Technolog
catalog.description: There is no digital architecture anymore: just architecture. Considers architecture in the expanded field of computational and media technologies within constructed environments. Complex assemblages of code, people, space, material, infrastructure, practices, and processes: each are technologies unto themselves as is their gathering in architecture.
catalog.subject: Architecture

catalog.title: Design for Real Estate Develpm
catalog.description: Course will examine selected topics in real estate development. Where appropriate, the course will incorporate guest speakers with expertise in real estate development, urban planning, architecture, environmental design, law, and community development, among other subjects. To solidly ground the classroom component of the course in a real-world context, the course will also require students to visit and analyze several development sites.
catalog.subject: Architecture

notes.note: This class meets in Hayes Hall 217.

catalog.title: Citizen Planning School
catalog.description: Citizen Planning School is a project-based, research-intensive, experiential learning course exploring the role of civic engagement in community-based planning and design efforts, promoting sustainable development in the Buffalo Niagara region through land use, transportation, housing, energy and climate, access to food, and more.  Through a combination of academic preparation and first-hand experience engaging with diverse public constituencies, students will hone skills, identify key gaps in community planning, design, development, and set the stage for a more sustainable Buffalo Niagara.  Citizen Planning School combines public engagement with action research to help meet the economic, environmental, and social challenges of the 21st century.  Includes lectures, discussions, fieldwork, and site visits. This course is the same as URP 636 and END 636.
catalog.subject: Architecture
catalog.long_title: Citizen Planning School: Regional Sustainability Through Community Engagement

catalog.title: Intel Domain: Ecological Pract
catalog.description: Offers students an intense exploration of the role that architects play in the design of the built and natural environments. Encourages multidisciplinary collaborations among allied professions and disciplines. Explores one or more of the following issues: how design, institutions, and governance structures may support or work against efforts to build a more sustainable society; social consequences of environmental issues; how different disciplines and people frame sustainability issues; how designers, policymakers, urban planners, and environmentalists apply frameworks to address sustainability problems; and other issues related to sustainable ecological practices. Topics vary annually. Includes lectures, discussions, site visits, and fieldwork.

catalog.title: Professional Practice
catalog.description: Phases of management involving architects from project inception to its realization. Office organization, contractor and owner management of projects, construction-cost analysis, organization and preparation of construction documents, review of related legal papers and standardized forms, alternative patterns of construction management relations. Emerging patterns of architectural practice.

catalog.title: Environmental Systems 3
catalog.description: Explores and synthesizes environmental systems for a design studio project, or investigates how these systems operate in an existing building as part of a semester-long project. Analyzes and examine how design criteria vary with factors like geography, climate, and construction type to develop evaluative measures. Using modeling or digital forensics tools, develop hypotheses based on these conditions to evaluate potential solutions for systems like active and passive heating and cooling, solar geometry, daylighting, natural ventilation, indoor air quality, solar systems, lighting, and/or acoustics. Upon conclusion of the course, students develop convincing representations of systems function to demonstrate how their decisions could be integrated with other building systems, including structural and thermal envelopes. Considers impacts on environmental building systems design, including form, structure, and material. Involves lecture, discussions, and fieldwork.
catalog.subject: Architecture
